subject   : Subject: FAITH A NECESSITY (2-1-2020)
from      : Pastor Sather <pastor.sather5@gmail.com>
to        : undisclosed-recipients:;
date      : Fri, 31 Jan 2020 18:50:26 -0600
===================================================================
Body (clean, unformatted):

*Today’s Verse:*

*The Lord said, “If you have faith as small as a mustard seed, you could
say to this mulberry tree, ‘Be pulled up by the roots and be*

*planted in the sea,’ and it would obey you. *(Lk. 17:6)



*Today’s Reflection:*

It’s truly important that we learn the true meaning of faith. First

it is trusting Jesus to save the day, *even* when we see no evidence

of His immediate power. According to the Bible, only a tiny speck of faith
is required to reap miracles. When anxiety sends our heart racing, we need
to stop what we are doing and calm ourselves.

Then continue our task as we wait on Jesus to move the mountain.

*Give Jesus all your pressing fears. Stand still and wait for Him*

*to fix what worries you.*

* Pastor Al*

of His immediate power. According to the Bible, only a tiny speck of faith is required to reap miracles. When anxiety sends our heart racing, we need to stop what we are doing and calm ourselves.
Then continue our task as we wait on Jesus to move the mountain. Give Jesus all your pressing fears. Stand still and wait for Him to fix what worries you.

prayer: Heavenly Father, we come to You with hearts filled with worry and anxious thoughts. Help us to remember the power of even the smallest seed of faith, as Your Word teaches. When our hearts race with fear, calm us and remind us to trust in Your perfect timing and plan. Give us the strength to stand still and wait for You to move the mountains that burden us. We surrender our pressing fears to You, Lord, and we await Your miraculous provision. Amen.

*Subject: FAITH PROVEN BY OBEDIENCE *(2-2-2020)



*Today’s Verse:*

*Whoever has My commandments and keeps them, he it is *

*who **loves Me. And he who loves Me will be loved by My Father, **and I
will love him and manifest Myself to him. *

(Jn. 14:21)



*Today’s Reflection:*

God loves and reveals Himself to those who love and

believe in Christ—a love shown by obedience to the

Word. Make yourself known then and seen beforehand,

lest you be *un*known for glory and known only for

punishment. *If Christ recognizes you in the **[present] *

*strife, He will recognize you in heaven. *

* Pastor Al*
original_reflection_text: God loves and reveals Himself to those who love and believe in Christ—a love shown by obedience to the Word. Make yourself known then and seen beforehand, lest you be un known for glory and known only for punishment. If Christ recognizes you in the [present] strife, He will recognize you in heaven.
original_verse_text: Whoever has My commandments and keeps them, he it is  who loves Me. And he who loves Me will be loved by My Father, and I will love him and manifest Myself to him.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You with grateful hearts, acknowledging that our love for You is shown through our obedience to Your Word. Help us to walk in the way of Your commandments, that we may know You more deeply and experience the fullness of Your love. May our lives be a reflection of Your glory, that we may be recognized by Christ both in this life and in the life to come. We ask this in the name of our Lord and Savior, Jesus Christ. Amen.
reflection: God loves and reveals Himself to those who love and believe in Christ—a love shown by obedience to the Word. Make yourself known then and seen beforehand, lest you be unknown for glory and known only for punishment. If Christ recognizes you in the present strife, He will recognize you in heaven.
subject: Faith Proven by Obedience

*Today’s Verse:*

*Whoever wants to become great*

*among **you, must be your **servant, *

*and whoever wants to be first must *

*be your slave—**just as the Son of *

*Man did not come to be served, but *

*to **serve, and give His life as a ransom for many. *(Mt. 20:26-28)



*Today’s Reflection:*

One thing to remember in the church,

is when we work together in harmony,

beautiful. Because our service is blessed by the Lord, we become a

greater blessing to Him, part of a vast and timeless host of worshipers.

*What part will you play in **Jesus’s*

*masterpiece today?*

* Pastor Al*

Use us, Lord, as part of Your masterpiece, to bless and honor You. Amen.

*Today’s Verse:*

*Be full of love for others, following the example of Christ **who loved
you and *

*gave Himself to God as a sacrifice to*

*take away your sins. And God was *

*pleased, for Christ’s **love for you was *

*like a sweet perfume. *(Eph. 5:2)



*Today’s Reflection:*

There is no greater example in all

Scriptures then the one we see in the

first line of (Eph. 5:2). *“Be full of love *

*for others, **following the example of Christ.” * How have we been doing?

Iknow in my own life I have surely

fallen short. A TRUE LOVE—is desires

to please Christ, it’s not something extra

for the Christian. It is basic to Christian sanctity. It is not a dessert,
but the main course—not a sideshow, but he main

tent. It is not a motive to which we can resort to when convenient; it is a
controlling force to which we have committed our lives. *This is the
lifestyle of love: The question we **need to ask ourselves is are we
pleasing Christ**?*

*Pastor Al *

*Today’s Verse:*

*There is a time for everything, a season *

*for every activity **under heaven. *(Eccl. 3:1) (read 3:1-8 for a clear
picture)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Timing is important. All the experiences listed in the first eight verses
of chapter eight are appropriate at certain times.The

secret to peace with God is to discover, accept, and appreciate God’s
perfect timing. The danger is to doubt or resent God’s timing. *This can
lead to despair, rebellion, **or moving ahead without **His *

*advice.*

* Pastor Al*
original_reflection_text: Timing is important. All the experiences listed in the first eight verses of chapter eight are appropriate at certain times.The secret to peace with God is to discover, accept, and appreciate God’s perfect timing. The danger is to doubt or resent God’s timing. This can lead to despair, rebellion, or moving ahead without His advice.
original_verse_text: There is a time for everything, a season  for every activity under heaven.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You, acknowledging that there is a time for everything under heaven, as Your Word declares. Help us to trust in Your perfect timing, even when we struggle to understand it. Grant us the wisdom to discern Your will and the patience to wait upon Your guidance. May we not doubt or resent Your timing, but instead find peace in the knowledge that You are sovereign over all things. In Your timing, may we experience the fullness of Your blessings. Amen.
reflection: Timing is important. *Today’s Verse:*

*You keep him in perfect peace whose mind is stayed on **You, because he
trusts in You. *(Isa. 26:3)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Keeping our mind focused on our Savior can take practice. With today’s
technology it is so easy to search the internet for different kinds of
information. If you have some troublesome thoughts today, bring them to
Jesus. If we bring our focus back to Jesus, our Savior, our mind will find
a place of peace. *Let’s clasp our hands, and look to Jesus, for true
peace.*

* Pastor Al*
original_reflection_text: Keeping our mind focused on our Savior can take practice. With today’s technology it is so easy to search the internet for different kinds of information. If you have some troublesome thoughts today, bring them to Jesus. If we bring our focus back to Jesus, our Savior, our mind will find a place of peace. Let’s clasp our hands, and look to Jesus, for true peace.
original_verse_text: You keep him in perfect peace whose mind is stayed on You, because he trusts in You.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You today with hearts that long for the peace that only You can provide. In the midst of the distractions and anxieties of this world, we fix our eyes on Jesus, our Savior and the source of true tranquility. Help us to cast our cares upon You, trusting in Your unfailing love and guidance. May our minds be steadfast, kept in perfect peace as we dwell on Your promises. We surrender our worries to You, Lord, and find rest in Your presence. Amen.
reflection: Keeping our minds focused on our Savior can take practice. With today's technology, it is so easy to search the internet for different kinds of information. message_id: 1701cf299f4a6e06
subject   : Subject: IS OUR SECULAR WISDOM FOOLISHNESS? (2-7-2020)
from      : Pastor Sather <pastor.sather5@gmail.com>
to        : undisclosed-recipients:;
date      : Thu, 6 Feb 2020 18:00:26 -0600
===================================================================
Body (clean, unformatted):
===================================================================
*Today’s Verse:*

*[A rich man] thought to himself. “What shall I do? I have **no place to
store my **crops—I will tear down my barns and **build bigger ones.” * (Lk.
12:17, 18)



*Today’s Reflections:*

“Wisdom may best describe our present scientific and cultural plateau,
yet spiritually
we are foolish for sure. Many men, seen as wise in the eyes of the world,
are

foolish in the eyes of our God. God, in no certain terms,

has said, “Fools make a mock at sin” (Prov. 14:9).

Our world says, “Do what makes you feel good; do your own thing!” God
has said. “He that trusts in his own heart is a fool” (Prov. 28:26).

The rich farmer in the twelfth chapter of Luke, who found comfort in his
accumulation of worldly goods, would be seen by many among us today as a
very wise

man. *But* God called him a fool (Luke: 12:20).

Our nation seems to be floating with the tide of moral and spiritual
corruption.

* Are you drifting with the tide, or are **you willing to *

*stem the tide—I would rather be fool in **the eyes of a **foolish **world,
than a fool in the eyes of my **all wise *

*Creator. *

* Pastor Al*
original_reflection_text:
“Wisdom may best describe our present scientific and cultural plateau, yet spiritually we are foolish for sure. Many men, seen as wise in the eyes of the world, are foolish in the eyes of our God. God, in no certain terms, has said, “Fools make a mock at sin” (Proverbs 14:9).
Our world says, “Do what makes you feel good;
do your own thing!” God has said. “He that trusts in his own heart is a fool” (Proverbs 28:26).
The rich farmer in the twelfth chapter of Luke, who found comfort in his accumulation of worldly goods, would be seen by many among us today as a very wise man. But God called him a fool (Luke: 12:20).
Our nation seems to be floating with the tide of moral and spiritual corruption. Are you drifting with the tide, or are you willing to stem the tide—I would rather be fool in the eyes of a foolish world, than a fool in the eyes of my all wise Creator.
original_verse_text: [A rich man] thought to himself. "What shall I do? I have no place to store my crops-I will tear down my barns and build bigger ones."
prayer: Heavenly Father, we confess that our wisdom often falls short of Your perfect understanding. Forgive us for being foolish in Your sight, chasing after the fleeting pleasures of this world rather than trusting in Your perfect plan. Help us to not rely on our own understanding, but to acknowledge You in all our ways, that You may direct our paths. May we be willing to be seen as fools in the eyes of the world, if it means being faithful to You, our all-wise Creator. In Jesus' name, Amen.
reflection: “Wisdom may best describe our present scientific and cultural plateau, yet spiritually we are foolish for sure. Many men, seen as wise in the eyes of the world, are foolish in the eyes of our God. God, in no uncertain terms, has said, “Fools make a mock at sin“ (Proverbs 14:9). Our world says, “Do what makes you feel good; do your own thing!“ God has said, “He that trusts in his own heart is a fool“ (Proverbs 28:26). But God called him a fool (Luke 12:20). Our nation seems to be floating with the tide of moral and spiritual corruption. Are you drifting with the tide, or are you willing to stem the tide? I would rather be a fool in the eyes of a foolish world, than a fool in the eyes of my all-wise Creator.

*Today’s Verse:*

*Then the man with one bag of silver came and said, “Master, I **knew you
are a hard man, harvesting crops you did not plant, **and gathering crops
you didn’t cultivate. I was afraid I would **lose your money, so *

*I hid it in the earth. Look here is your **money back.” *

(Mat. 25:24-25)



*Today’s Reflection:*

There have been times I have struggled with taking ownership of my
mistakes, until Jesus convinced

me to own up to them. Facing the truth that I was to

fault wasn’t easy. Taking the step To take ownership

of my struggle helped me understand other areas in

my life, and it put me on the path to transformation

and freedom.

* Do you make excuses or blame others to avoid*

*taking responsibility? *

* Pastor Al*
original_reflection_text:
There have been times I have struggled with taking ownership of my mistakes, until Jesus convinced me to own up to them. Facing the truth that I was to fault wasn’t easy. Taking the step To take ownership of my struggle helped me understand other areas in my life, and it put me on the path to transformation and freedom. Do you make excuses or blame others to avoid
taking responsibility?

prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You with humble hearts, acknowledging the times we have struggled to take responsibility for our own shortcomings. Forgive us for the tendency to point fingers and make excuses, rather than facing the truth about ourselves. Help us to have the courage to own our mistakes, that we may grow in wisdom and walk the path of transformation You have laid out for us. May we extend the same grace to others that You have so freely given to us. In Jesus' name, Amen.
reflection: There have been times I have struggled with taking ownership of my mistakes, until Jesus convinced me to own up to them. Facing the truth that I was at fault wasn't easy. Taking the step to take ownership of my struggle helped me understand other areas in my life, and it put me on the path to transformation and freedom. Do you make excuses or blame others to avoid taking responsibility?

subject   : Subject: NOT GOOD TO BE DETACHED (2-9-2020)

*Today’s Verse:*

*Let us consider one another in order to stir up love and*

*good works, not forsaking the assembling of ourselves*

*together, as is the manner of some, but exhorting one*

*another, and so much the more as you see the DAY*

*approaching. *(Heb. 10:24-25)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Of how much good is a church member, detached

from the rest? How much fruit can a branch bear, detached from the vine?
How good is your hand when

it is, detached from the body?

When we come together in the church as an assembly,

Paul wrote, we are to help each other to “stir up love

and good works.” We need love and good works to be

able to reach the unsaved in the world today. At times,

we need to just surround ourselves with the love of one

another and encourage each other, knowing that our

hope for all things is in our Savior, Jesus Christ.

* A Christian is one who stays with the rest of the*

*church.*

* Pastor Al*
original_reflection_text:

another and encourage each other, knowing that our
hope for all things is in our Savior, Jesus Christ.
A Christian is one who stays with the rest of the
church.

prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You as Your children, united in the body of Christ. Forgive us for the times we have become detached from the fellowship of believers, neglecting to stir up love and good works in one another. Help us to remember that we are stronger together, drawing strength and encouragement from the community of faith. May our love for one another be a testimony to the world of the transforming power of Your Son, Jesus Christ. In His name, we pray. Amen.
reflection: Of how much good is a church member, detached from the rest? How much fruit can a branch bear, detached from the vine? How good is your hand when it is, detached from the body? message_id: 1702c8493eeb51e3
subject   : Subject: DISCIPLINE ENCOURAGES SELF---CONTROL (2-10-2020)
from      : Pastor Sather <pastor.sather5@gmail.com>
to        : undisclosed-recipients:;
date      : Sun, 9 Feb 2020 18:34:11 -0600
===================================================================
Body (clean, unformatted):
===================================================================
*Today’s Verse:*

*No discipline is enjoyable while it is happening—it is*

*painful! Later on, however, it produces a harvest of*

*righteousness and peace for those who have been*

*trained by it. *Heb. 12:11)



*Today’s Reflection:*

We may respond to discipline in several ways:

(1) We can accept it with resignation;

(2) We can accept it with pity;

(3) We can be angry and resentful toward

God or

(4) We can accept it gratefully, as the
appropriate response we owe a

loving Father.

*When God corrects you, see it as proof of His love,*

*and ask Him what He is trying to teach you.*

* Pastor Al *
original_verse_text: No discipline is enjoyable while it is happening-it is painful! Later on, however, it produces a harvest of righteousness and peace for those who have been trained by it.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You with humble hearts, acknowledging that Your discipline is a sign of Your love and care for us. Help us to respond with gratitude, knowing that the trials we face are opportunities for growth and sanctification. Grant us the wisdom to see Your hand at work, even in the midst of our discomfort, that we may emerge from these times stronger in faith and more conformed to the image of Your Son. May we trust in Your perfect plan, and find joy in the knowledge that You are shaping us to be more like Christ. We surrender ourselves to Your loving guidance, and pray that Your will be done. Amen.
reflection: We may respond to discipline in several ways: (1) We can accept it with resignation; (2) We can accept it with pity; (3) We can be angry and resentful toward God; or (4) We can accept it gratefully, as the appropriate response we owe a loving Father. When God corrects you, see it as proof of His love, and ask Him what He is trying to teach you.
subject: Discipline Encourages Self---Control
verse_text: No discipline is enjoyable while it is happening-it is painful! Later on, however, it produces a harvest of righteousness and peace for those who have been trained by it.

*Today’s Verse:*

*And so, from the day we heard, we have not ceased *

*to pray for **you, asking that you may be filled **with *

*the **knowledge of His **will in all spiritual wisdom *

*and understanding.* (Col. 1:9)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Many of our church members are included in our

prayer chain. Whenever there is a prayer concern

or a praise report, text messages are sent to those

in the prayer group. Technology has allowed the

people to contact each other quickly and keep

everyone updated. Praying brings people closer

to Jesus; praying for others is good and pleasing in

the sight of our Savior. Jesus honors the prayers of

those who love Him. He unleashes hope, healing,

*Today’s Verse:*

*Let Him have all your worries and cares, for He is *

*always **thinking about you and watching everything *

*that concerns **you. *(I Pet. 5:7)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Just before His crucifixion, Jesus told His disciples, “Don’t let your
heart be troubled (Jn. 14:1). The question I have heard is how is this
possible in our

fallen world where terrible things happen every day? Jesus gave the answer at
the end of the verse: *“Trust [Believe *in some translations] in Me.” Do we
trust

Him with a scary medical diagnosis, a wayward

spouse or child, a sudden Job loss? If we trust

Jesus to take care of everything that concerns us,

then our faces will reflect that. *Look in the mirror.* *What message **does
your face reflect? Peace and trust in Jesus, or stress? **(Recite Jn 14:1
until you smile).*

* Pastor Al*

May our faces shine with the light of Your love, and our lives be a testament to the transformative power of faith in Jesus. Amen.

*Today’s Verse:*

*Jesus said…”You shall Love the Lord your God with all **your heart, with
all your soul, and with *

*all your mind. **This is the first and great command. And the second is **like
it, ‘You shall love your neighbor as yourself. *(Mt. 22:37-39)



*Today’s Reflection: *

When I was young I had to memorized these

verses but it became difficult for me to under-

stand the third part of this verse because I thought loving myself a vain,
prideful thing to do. In other words, not a Christian thing. But it was
explained to me that it grieves God when we treat ourselves

poorly. Just as it would if we treated a brother or

sister in Christ poorly. When you find yourself being to critical,
negative, or demanding with yourself today, ask yourself: *Is this how I
would treat my best friend?*

*[Then be kind to yourself.] Remember Jesus loves **you and wants you to
love yourself too.*

*Pastor Al*

In other words, not a Christian thing. But it was explained to me that it grieves God when we treat ourselves poorly. Just as it would if we treated a brother or sister in Christ poorly. When you find yourself being to critical, negative, or demanding with yourself today, ask yourself: Is this how I would treat my best friend? [Then be kind to yourself.] Remember Jesus loves you and wants you to love yourself too.

Help us to understand the importance of loving ourselves as You have loved us, for we are fearfully and wonderfully made in Your image. May we treat ourselves with the same kindness and compassion that we would extend to our closest friends. Guide us to see ourselves as You see us, and to find joy in the unique ways You have created us. We ask this in the name of Your Son, Jesus Christ. Amen.

*Today’s Verse:*

*that in **them you have eternal life. These are the very Scriptures **that
testify about me, yet you refuse to come *

*to me to have **life. *(Jn. 5:39-40)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Our lives are not just about the clamoring GPS of the

makes us miss our true Savior, Jesus leads us on a rich path. Each day,
each moment, is an opportunity *to* commune with Him, *to* learn to follow
Him*, to *allow Him to change us. *Yes, *He grants eternal life. *But* He
also grants eternal purpose to our present days. *Ask *

*Him to reveal His **purpose for you today.*

* Pastor Al*

*Today’s Verses:*

*Praise the Lord, all you nations. Praise Him, all you*

*people of the earth. For He loves us with unfailing*

*love; the faithfulness of the Lord endures forever.*

(Ps. 117:1-2)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Not only is Psalm 117 one of the shortest chapters in

the Bible, it is also the middle chapter. In Ro. 15:11

Paul quotes these verses to show that God’s salvation

is for all people not just Jews.

Have you ever said, “I can’t think of anything God

has done for me. How can I praise Him?” This Psalm

gives two reasons for praising God, *His unfailing love *

*toward us and His faithfulness lasts forever.* *If He did*

*nothing else for us, He would still be worthy of our *

*highest praise.*

* Pastor Al*

*Today’s Verse:*

*And all of us have had that veil removed so that we*

*can be mirrors that brightly reflect to glory of the*

*Lord . And as the Spirit of the Lord works within us, **we become more and
more like Him and reflect His **glory even more. *(2 Cor. 3:18)



*Today’s Reflection:*

The glory that the Spirit imparts to the believer is

more excellent and lasts longer than the glory that

Moses experienced. By gazing at the nature of God

with unveiled minds, we can be more like Him. In

the Good News we see the truth about Christ, and

it transforms us morally as we understand and apply it. Through learning
about Christ’s life, we can understand how wonderful God is and what he

really is like. As our knowledge deepens, the Holy

Spirit helps us to change. *Becoming Christlike*

*Is a progressive experience*. (Ro. 8:29)

*Pastor Al*

The glory that the Spirit imparts to the believer is
more excellent and lasts longer than the glory that
Moses experienced. By gazing at the nature of God
with unveiled minds, we can be more like Him. In
the Good News we see the truth about Christ, and
it transforms us morally as we understand and apply it.
Through learning about Christ’s life, we can understand how wonderful God is and what he
really is like. As our knowledge deepens, the Holy
Spirit helps us to change. Becoming Christlike Is a progressive experience. (Romans 8:29)
original_verse_text: And all of us have had that veil removed so that we can be mirrors that brightly reflect to glory of the Lord . And as the Spirit of the Lord works within us, we become more and more like Him and reflect His glory even more.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You with grateful hearts, marveling at the glory that Your Spirit imparts to us. As we gaze upon the nature of Christ with unveiled minds, transform us by the power of Your Word. May the truth of the Gospel shine brightly, illuminating our understanding and shaping us to be more like Your Son. By the work of the Holy Spirit, may this process of becoming Christlike continue, day by day, until we fully reflect Your glory. Amen.
reflection: The glory that the Spirit imparts to the believer is more excellent and lasts longer than the glory that Moses experienced. By gazing at the nature of God with unveiled minds, we can be more like Him. In the Good News, we see the truth about Christ, and it transforms us morally as we understand and apply it. Through learning about Christ's life, we can understand how wonderful God is and what He really is like. As our knowledge deepens, the Holy Spirit helps us to change. Becoming Christlike is a progressive experience. (Romans 8:29)
subject: A More Perfect Glory
verse_text: And all of us have had that veil removed so that we can be mirrors that brightly reflect to glory of the Lord . And as the Spirit of the Lord works within us, we become more and more like Him and reflect His glory even more.

*Today’s Verse:*

*Because I love Zion, because my heart yearns *

*for Jerusalem, **I cannot remain silent. I will not stop praying for her
until **her righteousness shine like the dawn. And her salvation **blazes
like a burning torch. *(Isa. 62:1)



*Today’s Reflection*

We should have Isaiah’s zeal to see God’s will done. This is what we mean
when we pray,

“May Your Kingdom come soon. May Your will

be done here on earth, just as it is in heaven.”

*It is good to keep praying persistently for others.*

* Pastor Al*
original_reflection_text:
We should have Isaiah’s zeal to see God’s will done. This is what we mean when we pray, “May Your Kingdom come soon. May Your will be done here on earth, just as it is in heaven.”
It is good to keep praying persistently for others.

prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You with hearts longing to see Your kingdom established and Your will done on earth as it is in heaven. Grant us the same zeal as the prophet Isaiah, that we may tirelessly pray and work for Your purposes to be fulfilled. May our petitions for others be persistent, trusting in Your perfect timing and sovereign plan. We surrender ourselves to You, that Your will may be done in our lives and in this world. Amen.

*Today’s Verse:*

*Be kind to each other, tenderhearted, forgiving *

*one **another, just as God through Christ has forgiven **you. *(Eph.
4:32) (read Eph. 4:28-31)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Remember we bring sorrow to the Holy Spirit

by the way we live. In verses 28-31 Paul warns

us against unwholesome language, bitterness, improper use of anger, harsh
words, slander, and

bad attitudes toward others. Instead of acting

that way, we should be forging just as God has forgiven us. Are you bring
sorrow or pleasing

God with your attitudes and actions? Act in love toward your brothers and
sisters in Christ. *We *

*are called to do that because **God acted in love by sending His Son to
die for our sins.*

* Pastor Al*

prayer: Heavenly Father, forgive us for the times we have brought sorrow to Your Holy Spirit through our unwholesome language, bitterness, and harsh words. Help us to put away all malice and, instead, be kind, tenderhearted, and forgiving towards one another, just as You have forgiven us through Your Son, Jesus Christ. May our attitudes and actions reflect Your love and grace. Amen.

*Today’s Verse:*

*Jesus told them, “This is what God wants you to do: Believe **in the One
He has sent.” *(Jn. 6:29)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Many sincere seekers were wondering what God

wanted them to do. Many of the religions of the world are mankind’s
attempts to answer this question. But Jesus’s reply is brief and simple. We
must believe on Him who God has sent. Remember this satisfying God does not
come from the works we do, but in whom we believe. The first step is
accepting that Jesus is who He claims to be. All spiritual development is
built on this affirmation. Now its up to you to; *Declare to Jesus, “You
are the Messiah, **the Son of the living God.*

* Pastor Al*

Help us to believe and declare with conviction that Jesus is the Messiah, the Son of the living God, for this is the foundation upon which all true spiritual growth is built. May our lives be a testament to our faith in You, the one true God, who has sent Your Son to be the way, the truth, and the life. Amen.

*Today’s Verse:*

*Thank God! For He gave us victory over sin and death*

*through our Lord Jesus Christ. *(I Cor. 15:57)



*Today’s Reflection:*

As we know Ash Wednesday ushers in Lent—a time of

reflection, self-sacrifice, spiritual discipline, and fasting

to prepare our hear for Easter. Ash Wednesday reminds

us of our morality (ashes to ashes, dust to dust) and our

sinfulness *but also* that our mortality and sin have been

conquered through the death and resurrection of our

Lord Jesus Christ. *Our humanity and our sinfulness*

*have been conquered in Jesus and we are free.*

* Pastor Al *
original_reflection_text:
As we know Ash Wednesday ushers in Lent—a time of

to prepare our hear for Easter. Ash Wednesday reminds
us of our morality (ashes to ashes, dust to dust) and our

conquered through the death and resurrection of our
Lord Jesus Christ. Our humanity and our sinfulness have been conquered in Jesus and we are free.

prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You with humble hearts, acknowledging our mortality and sinfulness. Yet, we rejoice in the truth that through the death and resurrection of our Lord Jesus Christ, our humanity and sin have been conquered. We are free from the wages of sin, which is death, and instead have been granted the gift of eternal life. Lord, as we enter this season of Lent, fill us with a spirit of reflection, self-sacrifice, and spiritual discipline, that we may be prepared to celebrate the victory of Your Son over sin and death. Amen.

*Today’s Verse:*

*Jesus answered, *(the Devil) *“It is written: ‘man shall *

*not live **by bread alone, but on every word that comes from the mouth **of
God.’” *(Mat. 4:4) read (Mt. 4:1-11)


*Today’s Reflection:*

Remember the Devil doesn’t play fare. At this particular

time Jesus had been in the wilderness—40 days and forty

nights with out food and the devil tried to tempt Jesus in

turning stones into loaves of beard. *But* Jesus was able

to resist the Devil's temptations because He not only knew Scripture, *but *He
also obeyed it. Ephesians 6:17 says that God’s Word is a sword to use in
spiritual combat. Knowing Bible verses is an important step in helping us
resist the Devil’s attacks, *but * we must also obey the Bible. If you read
Mt. 4;1-11 We see that Satan

had memorized Scriptures *but* *He failed to obey it.*

*The Bible help us follow God desires rather than*

*The Devil’s.*

* Pastor Al*

*Today’s Verse:*

*Therefore, since we are surrounded by so great a cloud*

*of witnesses, let us also lay aside every weight, and sin*

*which clings so closely, and let us run with endurance *

*the race that is set before us. *(Heb. 12:1)



*Today’s Reflection:*

(*The great cloud of witnesses*) are the people of faith

described in chapter 11. Their faithfulness should be

an encouragement to us. We do not struggle alone,

*and* we are not the first to struggle with problems we

face. Others have run the race and won, and their

witness should stir us run and win. The Christian life

involves hard work. *It requires us to give up whatever*

*endangers our relationship with God, so let us keep*

*our eyes on Jesus. We should be running for Him*

*not ourselves.*

* Pastor Al*

May their example and witness encourage us to lay aside every weight and sin that clings so closely, and to run with endurance the race set before us, keeping our eyes fixed on Jesus, the founder and perfecter of our faith. Grant us the strength and perseverance to press on toward the goal for the prize of the upward call of God in Christ Jesus. Amen.

*Today’s Verse:*

*Yea, though I walk through the valley of the *

*shadow of **death, I will fear no veil; for thou art with me: thy rod **and
thy staff they comfort me. *(Ps. 23:4)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Jesus is so careful with those He loves. He is constantly guarding us,
saving us, and lifting us

up. He is our shield and protector. He is our light

in the dark. Under His wings, we will find refuge. Know that He is
protecting you today.

*Ask Jesus to put a hedge of protection around *

*you and **your loved ones.*

* Pastor Al*

May we rest securely in the knowledge that You are our light, our refuge, and our ever-present help in times of trouble. We trust in Your unwavering love and care. Amen.
